sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction of 2 moles of magnesium oxide (MgO) with 2 moles of hydrochloric acid (HCl) to produce 2 moles of magnesium chloride (MgCl2) and 1 mole of water (H2O) at standard conditions? The enthalpies of formation for MgO, HCl, MgCl2, and H2O are -601.8 kJ/mol, -92.3 kJ/mol, -641.3 kJ/mol, and -285.8 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change, and ΔHf° is the standard enthalpy of formation.

For the given reaction:

2 MgO + 2 HCl → 2 MgCl2 + H2O

We have the following enthalpies of formation:

ΔHf°(MgO) = -601.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(HCl) = -92.3 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(MgCl2) = -641.3 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH° = [2(-641.3) + 1(-285.8)] - [2(-601.8) + 2(-92.3)]

ΔH° = (-1282.6 - 285.8) - (-1203.6 - 184.6)

ΔH° = -1568.4 - (-1388.2)

ΔH° = -180.2 kJ

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -180.2 kJ.
